Instrument.name: Energetic Particles Detector for GO
Instrument.description: The Galileo Energetic Particles Detector (EPD) is an advanced instrument designed to study the unique characteristics of Jupiter's extensive magnetosphere, which is distinguished by high trapped particle energies, diverse particle compositions, and significant co-rotational dynamics. Previous exploratory missions, such as Pioneer and Voyager, have highlighted the necessity for a robust instrument capable of addressing the complex parametric challenges posed by the Jovian environment. The EPD fulfills a dual purpose: it plays a critical role in shaping the magnetospheric dynamics by influencing solar wind interactions and it serves as a diagnostic tool for studying particle transport and energization mechanisms. Launched aboard the Galileo spacecraft in 1989, the EPD boasts comprehensive 4-pi steradian angular coverage, advanced energy measurement capabilities spanning from 0.02 to 55 MeV/nucl, and a novel ability to measure low-energy particles, bridging gaps present in earlier data. Significant advancements include close flybys of the Galilean satellites, enabling unprecedented observations of satellite-magnetosphere interactions, and the capacity for real-time processing of telemetry data across multiple energy measurements and spatial orientations. The detector incorporates dual solid-state telescopes—a Low Energy Magnetospheric Measurement System (LEMMS) and a Composition Measurement System (CMS)—each employing sophisticated techniques such as time-of-flight measurements and magnetic deflection to distinguish between particle species and delineate their energy spectra. As part of the ongoing mission, the Galileo EPD aims to accumulate and analyze a rich dataset that elucidates the intricacies of Jovian particle dynamics while adapting its operational parameters to meet telemetry constraints, thus ensuring maximal scientific return on investment.
